revision.comment: This article only describes body scanners for security purposes. Other body-scanning technologies are described in the [[3D body scanning]] article.
revision.text:
{{about|body scanners for security purposes|other body scanning technologies|3D body scanning}} [[File:NRW-Verkehrsminister Hendrik Wüst - Vorstellung Easy Security-6294.jpg|thumb|Full body scanner in millimeter wave scanners techniue at [[Cologne Bonn Airport]]]] {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Globalize/US|date=May 2012}} [[File:Mmw large.jpg|300px|thumb|Image from an active millimeter wave body scanner]] A '''full-body scanner''' is a device that detects objects on a person's body for security screening purposes, without physically removing clothes or making physical contact. Depending on the technology used, the operator may see an alternate-wavelength image of the person's naked body, or merely a cartoon-like representation of the person with an indicator showing where any suspicious items were detected. For privacy and security reasons, the display is generally not visible to other passengers, and in some cases is located in a separate room where the operator cannot see the face of the person being screened. Unlike [[metal detector]]s, full-body scanners can detect non-metal objects, which became an increasing concern after various airliner bombing attempts in the 2000s.
Starting in 2007, full-body scanners started supplementing metal detectors at airports and train stations in many countries.
Three distinct technologies have been used, though the use of Backscatter X-ray has now been discontinued in many countries: * [[Millimeter wave scanner]]s use non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation similar to that used by wireless data transmitters, in the [[Extremely high frequency|Extremely High Frequency (EHF)]] radio band (which is a lower frequency than visible light). The health risks posed by these machines are still being studied, and the evidence is mixed, though millimeter wave scanners do not generate [[ionizing radiation]]. <ref name="health_privacy">{{cite web|url=http://securitymanagement.com/news/companies-seek-full-body-scans-ease-health-privacy-concerns-006852 |work=Security Management |title=Companies Seek Full-Body Scans That Ease Health, Privacy Concerns |author=Harwood, Matthew |date=March 5, 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006112416/http://securitymanagement.com/news/companies-seek-full-body-scans-ease-health-privacy-concerns-006852 |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> * [[Backscatter X-ray]] machines use low dose penetrating radiation for detecting suspicious metallic and non-metallic objects hidden under clothing or in shoes and in the cavities of the human body.<ref>{{cite web|title='AMAZING RESULTS' OF THE SCANNER THAT 'SEES EVERYTHING' |url=http://www.domodedovo.ru/en/main/news/publ_press/?ID=1608 |work=Moscow Domodedovo Airport |date=October 2, 2006 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303102333/http://www.domodedovo.ru/en/main/news/publ_press/?ID=1608 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=mdy }}</ref> There has been considerable debate with regard to how safe this technology is. * Through-body [[X-Ray]] security scanners that emit a high level of radiation have been supplied by the US to at least two African countries. Passengers and advocates have objected to images of their naked bodies being displayed to screening agents or recorded by the government. Critics have called the imaging virtual strip searches without probable cause, and have suggested they are illegal and violate basic human rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/10/AR2011031003628.html|title=Group says body scanners an 'unreasonable search'|author=Pickler, Nedra |publisher=The Washington Post|date=March 10, 2011}}</ref> However, current technology is less intrusive and because of [[privacy]] issues most people are allowed to refuse this scan and opt for a traditional pat-down.
==History (US)== The first full body security scanner was developed by Dr. Steven W Smith,<ref name="Tek84.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.tek84.com/company.html |title=Steven W. Smith / Original Developer of Secure 1000 in 1992 |publisher=Tek84.com |date= |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100908095734/http://www.tek84.com/company.html |archivedate=September 8, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>Hamilton, John (January 14, 2010) [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=122499686 New Airport Body Scans Don't Detect All Weapons]. National Public Radio</ref> who developed the Secure 1000 whole body scanner in 1992. He subsequently sold the device and associated patents to [[Rapiscan Systems]], who now manufacture and distribute the device.
The first passive, non-radiating full body screening device was developed by [[Lockheed Martin]] through a sponsorship by the National Institute of Justice ([[NIJ]])'s Office of Science and Technology and the [[United States Air Force Research Laboratory]]. Proof of concept was conducted in 1995 through the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency ([[DARPA]]). Rights to this technology were subsequently acquired by [[Brijot|Brijot Imaging Systems]], who further matured a commercial-grade product line and now manufacture, market and support the passive millimeter wave devices.<ref>{{cite news |title=Brijot Acquires Rights to Lockheed Martin-Developed Technology for Design and Development of Concealed Weapons Detection Camera, Supporting Counter-Terrorism and Homeland Security Efforts |work=Business Wire |url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-90526909.html | location=Orlando | date=August 20, 2002}}</ref>
Safety aspects of the Secure 1000 have been investigated in the US by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] and [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements]] since the early 1990s.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
==Usage== {{Update|section|date=June 2013}} [[File:AIT Passenger Checkpoint Video.ogv|thumb|Video from the TSA explaining the procedure]] [[Schiphol]] in the [[Netherlands]] was the first [[airport]] in the world to implement this device on a large scale after a test with flight personnel the previous year. On May 15, 2007 two of 17 purchased security scans were installed.
Full-body scanners was installed in at least one Florida courthouse in 2010<ref>[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/08/05/feds_pervscan/ Feds admit storing pervscanner pics], The Register, August 5, 2010</ref> and have started to appear in courthouses around the US.<ref>Banda, P. Solomon. [https://web.archive.org/web/20101127182549/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101124/ap_on_re_us/us_courthouse_scanners Full-body scanners popping up at courthouses]. ''Associated Press'' via news.yahoo.com</ref>
At least one New Jersey [[Port Authority Trans-Hudson|PATH]] train station used full-body scanners during a two-week trial in 2006.<ref>[http://www.hudsoncity.net/tubes/securitytesting.html PATH train riders to face anti-terror screening: PATH Trains Hudson Tubes Hudson & Manhattan RR]. Hudsoncity.net. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20101123001002/http://securitysolutions.com/news/TrainBodyScans/ Train passengers subjected to infrared body scans]. Securitysolutions.com (July 14, 2006). Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
As of September 3, 2014, [[Transportation Security Administration]] reported that there were almost 740 Millimeter Wave AIT (Advanced Imaging Technology) <sup>[meaning needed]</sup> scanners now in use at 160 United States airports <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140903061725/http://www.tsa.gov/traveler-information/advanced-imaging-technology-ait Advanced Imaging Technology (AIT)]. tsa.gov</ref>
The US Government also hinted in 2010 at the possibility of deploying the full body scanners at train stations and subways.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sify.com/news/now-body-scanners-could-be-deployed-at-us-train-stations-subways-other-mass-transits-news-international-kl0rkpdbgja.html|title='Now 'body scanners' could be deployed at US train stations, subways, other mass transits'|publisher=sify|date=November 26, 2010}}</ref>
The Italian government had planned to install full-body scanners at all airport and train stations throughout the country, but announced in September 2010 plans to remove the scanners from airports, calling them "slow and ineffective."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/travel/travel-news/italy-to-abandon-airport-body-scanners-20100924-15pgu.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Italy to abandon airport body scanners | date=September 24, 2010}}</ref>
The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has stated in 2010 they "[have] not, will not and the machines cannot store images of passengers at airports".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/08/tsa-response-to-feds-admit-storing.html |title=The TSA Blog: TSA Response to “Feds admit storing checkpoint body scan images” |publisher=Blog.tsa.gov |date=August 6, 2010 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> However the TSA later disclosed, in a response to the house chair on homeland security, that its procurement of airport scanners requires manufacturers to include image storage and transmission features but that these features should be disabled before being placed in an airport. The TSA shows 45 individuals have the ability to turn these machines into 'test mode' which enables recording images, but states that they would never do this on a production system.<ref>Rossides, Gale D. (February 24, 2010) [https://epic.org/privacy/airtravel/backscatter/TSA_Reply_House.pdf Letter to Bennie G. Thompson]. </ref> The US Marshal Service did operate a backscatter machine in a courthouse which records images. However, in a statement they noted that only individuals involved in a test were recorded. A sample of these images was received and disseminated by Gizmodo in 2010, using a Freedom Of Information Request.<ref name="MSNBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40218074/ns/technology_and_science-security|title=Leaked U.S. Marshal body scan images revealed|author=Rothman, Wilson |publisher=MSN|date=November 16, 2010 }}</ref> It is not clear if the US Marshal service has put these new scanning machines, that have recording capabilities, into production.
The analyst is in a different room and is not supposed to be able to see the person being scanned by the Backscatter X-Ray AIT, but is in contact with other officials who can halt the scanned person if anything suspicious shows up on the scan.
In the U.S. TSA currently uses Millimeter Wave AIT scanners exclusively, which show no identifying characteristics of the person being scanned. Instead, a generic outline of a person is used.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150503061337/http://www.tsa.gov/ait-how-it-works AIT: How it Works]. U.S. Transportation Security Administration </ref> As of December 2015, "While passengers may generally decline AIT screening in favor of physical screening, TSA may direct mandatory AIT screening for some passengers as warranted by security considerations in order to safeguard transportation security."<ref name=Vaughan>Vaughan, Jill (December 18, 2015) [https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/privacy-tsa-pia-32-d-ait.pdf Privacy Impact Assessment: Update for TSA Advanced Imaging Technology]. U.S. Department of Homeland Security</ref>
The [[European Union]] currently allows member states to decide whether to implement full body scanners in their countries:<ref>[http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/aviation-security.56u/ Member States must decide on airport body scanners: EC – EU business news]. EUbusiness.com (June 16, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
{{quote|It is for each member state to decide to authorise the use of scanners in national airports. That will not change ... But where this scanning technology is used it should be covered by EU-wide standards on detection capability as well as common safeguards to ensure compliance with EU health and fundamental rights provisions.|EU Transport Commissioner Siim Kallas}}
In Australia the Government has decided a no opt-out policy will be enforced in relation to screening at airports. Persons with medical or physical conditions that prevent them from undertaking a body scan will be offered alternative screening methods suitable to their circumstances. Infants and young children under 140 cm will not be selected to undergo a body scan.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160709151224/http://travelsecure.infrastructure.gov.au/bodyscanners/faq.aspx Airport Body Scanners—Frequently Asked Questions]. Australian Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development</ref> Body-scanners are being used at eight of Australia’s international airports – Adelaide, Brisbane, Cairns, Darwin, Gold Coast, Melbourne, Perth and Sydney.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150722073956/http://www.jetstar.com/au/en/planning-and-booking/booking-with-jetstar/body-scanners Body scanners]. jetstar.com</ref> So far only passengers exiting via international flights are affected.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-02-06/privacy-questions-over-airport-body-scan-laws/3813760 |title=No opt-out rule for airport body scanners – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> Passengers who refuse a scan may be banned from flying.<ref>Puhanic, Andrew. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120614032820/http://www.theglobalistreport.com/australia-becomes-first-to-ban-travelers-who-refuse-naked-body-scanners/ Australia Becomes First to Ban Travelers Who Refuse Naked Body Scanners]. theglobalistreport.com</ref> The scanners proposed to be used in Australia have shown a high rate of error in testing.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.news.com.au/travel/news/airport-body-scanner-testing-in-austrlia-shows-high-error-rate/story-e6frfq80-1226176949471 | work=news.com.au | title=Airport body scanner testing in Australia shows high error rate | date=October 26, 2011}}</ref> Public outrage over the nude images created by the body scanners being collected by policy resulted in a lawsuit in 2010 to stop body scanning.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/travel/news/naked-scanner-outrage-as-images-stored/story-e6frg8ro-1225903854864 | first=Kate | last=Schneider | title=Outrage as 'naked scans' stored by police | date=August 11, 2010 | work=The Australian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-6057400-504083.html |work=CBS News |title=Do New Airport Body Scanners Violate Child Porn Laws? Brits Balking at US Security Demands |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120825090155/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-6057400-504083.html |archivedate=August 25, 2012 }}</ref>
In Canada 24 airports currently have these scanners in use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citynews.ca/2015/01/14/interactive-map-canadian-airports-with-full-body-scanners/ |title=INTERACTIVE MAP: Canadian airports with full body scanners – CityNews |publisher=Citynews.ca |date=January 14, 2015 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> "Passengers selected for a secondary search can choose between the full body scanner or a physical search."<ref>Transport Canada [https://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/mediaroom/infosheets-menu-7669.html]</ref>
Civil rights groups in Britain in 2010 argued that the body scanning of children contravened the law relating to [[child pornography]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/airport-scanners-could-break-child-porn-laws/story-fn3dxix6-1225816311648 | title=Airport scanners 'could break child porn laws' | date=January 5, 2010 | work=The Australian}}</ref>
==Controversies== {{criticism section|date=February 2015}}
The implementation of widespread full-body scanners has raised a public controversy.
===Privacy=== Some argue that the use of full-body scanners is equivalent to a strip search, and that if used without probable cause this violate basic human rights.<ref>[https://www.aclu.org/technology-and-liberty/aclu-backgrounder-body-scanners-and-virtual-strip-searches "ACLU Backgrounder on Body Scanners and 'Virtual Strip Searches'"], American Civil Liberties Union. Aclu.org (January 8, 2010). Retrieved on 2011-11-01.</ref><ref>[http://epic.org/privacy/airtravel/backscatter/ Whole Body Imaging Technology and Body Scanners ("Backscatter" X-Ray and Millimeter Wave Screening)]. EPIC. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/13/nation/la-na-terror-privacy13-2010jan13|title=The fight against full-body scanners at airports|author=Savage, David G. |publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=January 13, 2010}}</ref>
Full-body scanning technology allows screeners to see the surface of the skin under clothing,<ref>[http://www.bild.de/BILD/news/bild-english/world-news/2009/12/31/pregnancy-body-piercings-genitals/what-can-naked-scanners-really-see.html "Pregnancy intimate piercings genitals – What can the naked scanner really see"], ''[[Bild]]'' (December 31, 2009). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> prosthetics including [[breast prostheses]] and prosthetic testicles, which may require a potentially embarrassing, physical inspection once detected. The scanners can also detect other medical equipment normally hidden, such as [[colostomy bag]]s and [[catheter]]s.<ref name="urlwww.dhs.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/privacy/privacy_pia_tsa_wbi.pdf |title=Privacy Impact Assessment for TSA Whole Body Imaging |work= |accessdate=October 19, 2009}}</ref> The transgender community also has privacy concerns<ref>[http://www.airlinereporter.com/2010/08/we-do-not-have-all-the-same-body-parts-and-body-scanners-violates-your-privacy/ We Do NOT Have All the Same Body Parts and Body Scanners Violates Your Privacy | Airline Reporter | An airline blog on the airline industry]. Airline Reporter (August 19, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> that body scanners could potentially lead to their harassment.
In the UK, in 2010, the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]] argued that full-body scanners were a risk to human rights and might be breaking the law.<ref>[http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/media-centre/2010/february/commission-issues-warning-over-counter-terrorism-measures/ EHRC – Commission issues warning over counter-terrorism measures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809193539/http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/media-centre/2010/february/commission-issues-warning-over-counter-terrorism-measures/ |date=August 9, 2010 }}. Equalityhumanrights.com (February 16, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref><ref>[http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23796214-body-scanners-human-rights-risk.do Body scanners 'human rights risk'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100119020731/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23796214-body-scanners-human-rights-risk.do |date=January 19, 2010 }}. Thisislondon.co.uk (January 17, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
A ruling of the [[European Council]] in 2013 required that person analyzing the image shall be in a separate location and the image shall not be linked to the screened person.<ref>"EU Sets Rules for Full Body Scanners." Air Transport World 49.1 (2012): 18.</ref>
In 2010 the [[National Human Rights Commission of Korea]] opposed the use of full-body scanners and recommended that they were not deployed at airports.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/skorean-human-rights-body-opposes-airport-body-scanners-2015338.html|title=S.Korean human rights body opposes airport body scanners|publisher=The Independent | location=London|date=July 1, 2010}}</ref>
Opponents in the US argue that full body scanners and the new TSA patdowns are unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/24/AR2010112404510.html|title=Why the TSA pat-downs and body scans are unconstitutional|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref> A comprehensive student note came out in the Fall 2010 issue of the [[University of Denver Transportation Law Journal]] that argued that the full-body scanners are unconstitutional in the United States because they are (1) too invasive and (2) not effective enough because the process is too inefficient.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Welch, Andrew |url=http://law.du.edu/documents/transportation-law-journal/past-issues/v37-03/Welch-Body-Scanners.pdf |title=Full-Body Scanners: Full Protection from Terrorist Attacks or Full-On Violation of the Constitution? |journal=Transportation Law Journal |volume=37 |date=2010|pages=167–198}}</ref>
On July 2, 2010, the [[Electronic Privacy Information Center]] (EPIC) filed a lawsuit to suspend the deployment of full-body scanners at airports in the United States:<ref>[http://epic.org/privacy/body_scanners/epic_v_dhs_suspension_of_body.html v. DHS (Suspension of Body Scanner Program)]. EPIC. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref> {{quote|EPIC argued that the federal agency has violated the Administrative Procedures Act, the Privacy Act, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, and the Fourth Amendment. EPIC cited the invasive nature of the devices, the TSA's disregard of public opinion, and the impact on religious freedom.|epic.org}}
EPIC claimed at that time that the full-body scanners violated the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] because they subject citizens to virtual strip searches without any evidence of wrongdoing.<ref>[http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2010/08/04/lawsuit_challenges_airport_full_body_scanners/ "Lawsuit challenges airport full-body scanners"], ''The Boston Globe'' (August 4, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
The [[American Civil Liberties Union]], in 2006, called the machines an invasion of privacy: "This doesn't only concern genitals but body size, body shape and other things like evidence of mastectomies, colostomy appliances or catheter tubes. These are very personal things that people have every right to keep private and personal, aside from the modesty consideration of not wanting to be naked."<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/12/05/1165080915144.html "Airport X-ray labelled strip search"'], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' (December 5, 2006). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
In [[Idaho]] a bill was introduced in 2011 to prevent the use of full-body scanners as a primary screening method, and to allow people to request alternative screening methods.<ref name="legislature.idaho.gov">[http://legislature.idaho.gov/legislation/2010/H0573.pdf Legislature of the State of Idaho, House Bill No. 573] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620221555/http://www.legislature.idaho.gov/legislation/2010/H0573.pdf |date=June 20, 2010 }}. (PDF) . Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
Travelers at U.S. airports have complained that when they opted not to be scanned, they were subjected to a new type of invasive pat-down that one traveler in 2010 described as "probing and pushing ... in my genital area."<ref>[http://motherjones.com/blue-marble/2010/08/tsas-new-gropey-pat-downs TSA's Frisky New Pat-Downs]. Mother Jones (August 24, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref><ref>[http://www.bostonherald.com/business/general/view/20100823passengers_shocked_by_new_touchy-feely_tsa_screening/srvc=business&position=also Passengers shocked by new touchy-feely TSA screening]. BostonHerald.com (August 24, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> Another traveler in the United States complained in 2010 that the TSA employee "inserted four fingers of both hands ''inside'' my trousers and ran his fingers all the way around my waist, his fingers extending at least 2–3 inches ''below'' my waistline."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rutherford.org/articles_db/commentary.asp?record_id=681|title=Michael Roberts: One Man Against the Surveillance State|last=Whitehead|first=John W.|date=October 25, 2010|work=The Rutherford Institute|accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref>
As of December 15, 2015 the TSA published a new policy which required AIT to be "mandatory" for "some" passengers for "security reasons".<ref name=Vaughan/> However, most individuals in the US can still opt out of the scanner and choose a pat-down if they are uncomfortable going through the scanner. Individuals also have the right to be patted down in a private room and have it witnessed by a person of the individual's choice.<ref>{{cite web|last=Greenberg|first=Peter|title=The Facts About TSA Body Scanners|url=http://www.arp.org|publisher=AARP|accessdate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>
In November 2010, a female traveler who opted out of a full body scan at Fort Lauderdale International Airport claimed that TSA agents handcuffed her to a chair and ripped up her plane ticket when she asked them questions about the new type of invasive pat down she was about to receive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.miaminewtimes.com/riptide/2010/11/meg_mclain_tells_of_horrifying.php|title=Meg McLain Tells of Horrifying Body Scanner Incident at Ft. Lauderdale Airport|last=Munzenrieder|first=Kyle|date=Nov 10, 2010|work=Miami News|accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref> In response, the [[Transportation Security Administration|TSA]] posted parts of the security camera footage on their blog, though there is no sound in the video and the passenger is not directly in the camera during most of the incident.<ref>[http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/11/response-to-female-radio-host-cuffed-to.html The TSA Blog: Response to "Female radio host cuffed to chair, ticket ripped up..."]. Blog.tsa.gov (November 11, 2010). Retrieved on 2011-11-01.</ref>
[[File:Brijot SafeScreen.jpg|thumb|Passive millimeter wave image and subject being screened]]
{{quote|Wholebody imaging technology may not be used as the sole or primary method of screening persons, nor may it be used to screen any person unless another method of screening, such as metal detection, demonstrates cause for preventing such person from boarding an aircraft or entering a public facility or government building.|Idaho House Bill no. 573}}
In the United States, in 2010 the [[Transportation Security Administration|TSA]] required that their full-body scanners "allow exporting of image data in real time",<ref name="epic.org">[http://epic.org/open_gov/foia/TSA_Procurement_Specs.pdf Procurement specification for whole body imager devices for checkpoint operations], U.S. Department of Homeland Security</ref> and cases of the government's storing of images have been confirmed.<ref>McCullagh, Declan. (August 4, 2010) [http://news.cnet.com/8301-31921_3-20012583-281.html Feds admit storing checkpoint body scan images]. News.cnet.com. Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
In August 2010, it was reported that [[United States Marshals Service]] saved thousands of images from a millimeter wave scanner.<ref name="CB2">{{cite web| last=Lundin|first=Leigh |title=You show me yours and ... |url=http://www.criminalbrief.com/?p=13511|work=Florida News |publisher=Criminal Brief |location=Orlando |date=August 15, 2010 |quote=Remember Homeland Security told the public the scanners aren't capable of storing images? Someone forgot to tell the scanner at the federal courthouse in Orlando ... }}</ref><ref>[http://video.foxnews.com/v/4303191/peep-show-database-of-american-travelers/?playlist_id=86919 'Peep Show Database of American Travelers' – Video – FoxNews.com]. Video.foxnews.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref> TSA – part of the Department of Homeland Security – reiterated that its own scanners do not save images and that the scanners do not have the capability to save images when they are installed in airports.<ref>[http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/08/tsa-response-to-feds-admit-storing.html The TSA Blog: TSA Response to "Feds admit storing checkpoint body scan images"]. Blog.tsa.gov (June 8, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> However, these statements contradict the TSA's own Procurement Specs which specifically require that the machines have the ability to record and transmit images, even if those features might be initially turned off on delivery.<ref name="epic.org" /> Opponents have also expressed skepticism that if there were a successful terror attack that the machines would not have the capability to save images for later inspection to find out what went wrong with the scans. On November 16, 2010, 100 of the stored 35,000 body scan images were leaked online and posted by [[Gizmodo]].<ref name="MSNBC" />
In February 2012 airport employees in [[Lagos]] were allegedly discovered wandering away from a cubicle located in a hidden corner on the right side of the screening area to where the 3D full-body scanner monitors are located.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201009210101.html|title=Now Showing at MMIA: Nude Images of Passengers|last=Eze|first=Chinedu|date=September 21, 2010|work=[[AllAfrica.com]]|accessdate=November 30, 2010|location=Lagos}}</ref> At the Dallas Ft. Worth International Airport, TSA complaints have been reported to disproportionally stem from women who felt that they were singled out for repeated screening for the entertainment of male security officers.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/02/female-body-scans/ | work=Wired | first=Kim | last=Zetter | title=Female Passengers Say They Were Targeted for TSA Body Scanners | date=February 14, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Allen |first=Ginger |url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2012/02/03/female-passengers-say-theyre-targeted-by-tsa/ |title=Female Passengers Say They’re Targeted By TSA « CBS Dallas / Fort Worth |publisher=Dfw.cbslocal.com |date=February 3, 2012 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.heraldsun.com.au/travel/news/womans-cute-figure-lands-her-in-a-spot-of-bother-at-airport/story-fn32891l-1226271803366 Security body scans 'cute' mum three times in Dallas airport]. NewsComAu (February 15, 2012)</ref>
===Treatment of minorities===
Current [[Backscatter X-ray|backscatter]] and [[millimeter wave scanner]]s installed by the TSA are unable to screen adequately for security threats inside turbans, hijab, burqas, casts, prosthetics and loose clothing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.queenstribune.com/deadline/Deadline_012011_SikhsCautioned.html |title=Sikhs Cautioned Over 'Random' Air Searches |author=Orovic, Joseph |publisher=Queens Tribune |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402060151/http://www.queenstribune.com/deadline/Deadline_012011_SikhsCautioned.html |archivedate=April 2, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/americas/2007/08/2008525141141752646.html|title=Sikh outrage at US airport security|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=August 26, 2007}}</ref> This technology limitation of current scanners often requires these persons to undergo additional screening by hand or other methods and can cause additional delay or feelings of harassment.<ref>[http://www.cairchicago.org/2010/11/22/travel-advisory-know-your-rights-if-asked-to-undergo-new-tsa-enhanced-pat-downs TRAVEL ADVISORY: Know Your Rights if Asked to Undergo New TSA 'Enhanced Pat-Downs']. CAIR-Chicago. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
According to a manufacturer of the machines, the next generation of backscatter scanners will be able to screen all types of clothing.<ref>[http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner.html Tek84] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208202236/http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner.html |date=December 8, 2013 }}. Tek84 (March 17, 2010). Retrieved on 2011-11-01.</ref> These improved scanners have been designed to equalize the screening process for religious minorities.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
===Treatment of transgender people===
Current machines installed by the TSA require agents in the US to designate each passenger as either male or female, after which the software compares the passenger's body against a normative body of that sex.<ref>{{cite web|title=Transgender Passengers|url=https://www.tsa.gov/transgender-passengers|website=Transportation Security Administration|accessdate=October 10, 2016|date=November 23, 2015}}</ref> Transgender passengers have reported that full body scanners at several U.S. airports have falsely raised alarms based on their anatomy.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rogers|first1=Katie|title=T.S.A. Defends Treatment of Transgender Air Traveler|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/23/us/shadi-petosky-tsa-transgender.html|accessdate=October 10, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=September 22, 2015}}</ref> The National [[LGBT]] Task Force asserts that policies related to these machines "codify discrimination against transgender people."<ref>{{cite web|title=New TSA Policy Codifies Discrimination Against Transgender People|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/new-tsa-policy-codifies-discrimination-against-transgender-people/|website=National LGBTQ Task Force|accessdate=October 10, 2016|date=March 4, 2016}}</ref>
===Health concerns=== There have been health concerns relating to the use of full body scanning technology, especially the use of x-ray scanners.
====Millimeter wave scanners==== {{Main article|Millimeter wave scanner}} Currently adopted millimeter wave scanners operate in the millimeter or sub-terahertz band, using [[non-ionizing radiation]], and have no proven adverse health effects, though no long term studies have been done.<ref name="businessweek.com" /> Thomas S. Tenforde, president of the National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements, said in 2010 that millimeter wave scanners are probably within bounds [of standards for safe operation], but there should be an effort to verify that they are safe for frequent use.<ref name="businessweek.com" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Hayes |first=John C. |url=http://www.diagnosticimaging.com/safety/content/article/113619/1509059 |title=Whole-body airport scanners are basically safe—or are they? |publisher=Diagnosticimaging.com |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> WHO (World Health Organization) in 2011 categorized RF (radio frequency) radiation as a possible carcinogen,<ref name=Wall Street Journal,10-3-14.
Numerical simulations of [[terahertz radiation]], which active millimeter wave scanners do not operate at, have produced mixed results. Researchers at the Center for Nonlinear Studies at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] in New Mexico have used simulations to show a way that terahertz radiation may affect DNA ,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Alexandrov|first1=B.S.|title= DNA Breathing Dynamics in the Presence of a Terahertz Field|journal=Physics Letters A|date=October 29, 2009|volume=374|issue=10|pages=1214|doi=10.1016/j.physleta.2009.12.077|pmid=20174451|pmc=2822276|arxiv=0910.5294 |bibcode=2010PhLA..374.1214A}}</ref> however this has not been verified.
====Backscatter X-ray scanners==== In the United States, the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 required that all full-body scanners operated in airports by the [[Transportation Security Administration]] use "Automated Target Recognition" software, which replaces the picture of a nude body with the cartoon-like representation.<ref name="abandons">{{cite news |url= https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2013/01/tsa-abandons-nude-scanners/|title=TSA Pulls Plug on Airport Nude Body Scanners |date= 2013-01-18| first=David | last=Kravets}}</ref> As a result of this law, all backscatter X-ray machines formerly in use by the Transportation Security Administration were removed from airports by May 2013, since the agency said the vendor (Rapiscan) did not meet their contractual deadline to implement the software.<ref>{{Citation | title = Rapiscan backscatter contract | date=Jan 2013 | publisher=TSA | format= [[World wide Web]] log | url= http://blog.tsa.gov/2013/01/rapiscan-backscatter-contract.html}}.</ref>
In the European Union, backscatter X-ray screening of airline passengers was banned in 2012 to protect passenger safety, and the deployment at [[Manchester Airport]] was removed.
[[File:Backscatter large.jpg|thumb|Some backscatter technology produces an image that resembles a chalk etching, though other configurations produce much more detailed images, and there is still a possibility that the lower quality images can be easily switched to a higher resolution.<ref>[http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/how_it_works.shtm TSA: How it Works] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203000000/http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/how_it_works.shtm |date=December 3, 2010 }}. Tsa.gov. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>]]
Several radiation safety authorities including the [[National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements]], The Health Physics Society, and the [[American College of Radiology]], have stated that they are "not aware of any evidence"<ref>[http://www.acr.org/MainMenuCategories/media_room/FeaturedCategories/PressReleases/StatementonAirportFullbodyScanners.aspx ACR Statement on Airport Full-body Scanners and Radiation]. Acr.org. Retrieved on November 1, 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628111902/http://www.acr.org/MainMenuCategories/media_room/FeaturedCategories/PressReleases/StatementonAirportFullbodyScanners.aspx |date=June 28, 2010 }}</ref> that full-body scans are unsafe.<ref name="blog.tsa.gov">[http://blog.tsa.gov/2010/03/advanced-imaging-technology-radiation.html The TSA Blog: Advanced Imaging Technology: "Radiation Risk Tiny"]. Blog.tsa.gov. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref> However, other radiation authorities, including the International Atomic Energy Agency and Nuclear Energy Agency recommend against using ionizing radiation on certain populations like pregnant women and children,<ref>Tirone, Jonathan. (February 5, 2010) [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aoG.YbbvnkzU&pos=11 Airport Body Scanning Raises Radiation Exposure, Committee Says]. Bloomberg. Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> and opponents of the devices say that no long-term studies have been done on the health effects of either backscatter x-ray or millimeter wave scanners:<ref>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/experts-call-for-more-study-into-body-scanners/article1423067/ Experts call for more study into body scanners]. The Globe and Mail (January 7, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> "I don't think the right questions have been asked. We don't have enough information to make a decision on whether there's going to be a biological effect or not". ([[Douglas Boreham]], professor in Medical Physics and Applied Radiation Sciences at [[McMaster University]] in Hamilton, Ont.)
Richard Morin, a medical physicist at the Mayo Clinic has said that he is not concerned about health effects from backscatter x-ray scanners:<ref name="businessweek.com">[http://www.businessweek.com/lifestyle/content/healthday/634724.html Airport Full Body Scanners Pose No Health Threat: Experts] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101120020329/http://www.businessweek.com/lifestyle/content/healthday/634724.html |date=November 20, 2010 }} . ''BusinessWeek'' (January 8, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> "From a radiation standpoint there has been no evidence that there is really any untoward effect from the use of this device [backscatter scanner], so I would not be concerned about it from a radiation dose standpoint – the issues of personal privacy are a different thing". The health effects of the more common millimeter wave scanner are largely unknown, and at least one expert believes a safety study is warranted. "I am very interested in performing a National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements study on the use of millimeter-wave security screening systems," said Thomas S. Tenforde, council president. However, no long-term studies have been done on the health effects of millimeter wave scanners.
Perhaps the most notable and debated professional opinion in regard to the safety of scanners is the so-called "Holdren Letter" from a number of world-renowned biochemists and biophysics researchers from the University of California to the Assistant to the US President for Science and Technology, Dr. John P. Holdren (Co-author of EcoSolutions). The opening paragraph of their letter of concern reads: "We, a number of University of California, San Francisco faculty, are writing—see attached memo—to call your attention to our concerns about the potential serious health risks of the recently adopted whole body back scatter X-ray airport security scanners. This is an urgent situation as these X-ray scanners are rapidly being implemented as a primary screening step for all air travel passengers."<ref>[https://shadowproof.com/letter-from-john-w-sedat-et-al-on-the-dangers-of-tsa-backscatter-scanners/ Letter from John W. Sedat et. al. on the Dangers of TSA Backscatter Scanners]. April 6, 2010</ref>
Critics of backscatter x-ray scanners, including the head of the [[Center for Radiological Research]] at [[Columbia University]], say that the radiation emitted by some full-body scanners is as much as 20 times stronger than officially reported and is not safe to use on large numbers of persons because of an increased risk of cancer to children and at-risk populations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/7862265/Airport-body-scanners-could-give-you-cancer.html|title=Airport body scanners 'could give you cancer'|author=Bloxham, Andy |publisher=The Telegraph|location=London|date=June 29, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/health/Some |title=Some full-body scanners not without cancer risk: Experts |publisher=Canwest News Service |author=Tam, Pauline |date=January 22, 2010 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115144315/http://www.canada.com/health/Some+full+body+scanners+without+cancer+risk+Experts/2472370/story.html |archivedate=November 15, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/292414|date=May 23, 2010 |title=Radiation from airport scanners may increase cancer risk|author=Lindner, Bill |publisher=Digital Journal}}</ref> Researchers at the [[University of California, San Francisco]], (UCSF) have argued that the amount of radiation is higher than claimed by the TSA and body scanner manufacturers because the doses were calculated as if distributed throughout the whole body, but the radiation from backscatter x-ray scanners is focused on just the skin and surrounding tissues:<ref name="scribd.com" /><ref>Carmichael, Scott. (May 18, 2010) [http://www.gadling.com/2010/05/18/scientists-question-safety-of-airport-full-body-scanners/ Scientists question safety of airport full body scanners]. Gadling.com. Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref><ref>[http://www.radiology.ucsf.edu/patient-care/patient-safety/radiation The risk of 'low dose radiation is controversial']. Radiology.ucsf.edu (February 14, 2010). Retrieved on 2011-11-01.</ref>
<blockquote>The majority of [the scanners'] energy is delivered to the skin and the underlying tissue. Thus, while the dose would be safe if it were distributed throughout the volume of the entire body, the dose to the skin may be dangerously high.
The X-ray dose from these devices has often been compared in the media to the cosmic ray exposure inherent to airplane travel or that of a chest X-ray. However, this comparison is very misleading: both the air travel cosmic ray exposure and chest X- rays have much higher X-ray energies and the health consequences are appropriately understood in terms of the whole body volume dose. In contrast, these new airport scanners are largely depositing their energy into the skin and immediately adjacent tissue, and since this is such a small fraction of body weight/vol, possibly by one to two orders of magnitude, the real dose to the skin is now high.
In addition, it appears that real independent safety data do not exist. A search, ultimately finding top FDA radiation physics staff, suggests that the relevant radiation quantity, the Flux [photons per unit area and time (because this is a scanning device)] has not been characterized. Instead an indirect test (Air Kerma) was made that emphasized the whole body exposure value, and thus it appears that the danger is low when compared to cosmic rays during airplane travel and a chest X-ray dose.</blockquote>
However other professors in the UCSF radiology department disagree, saying that the radiation dose is low.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sfweekly.com/thesnitch/2010/11/tsa_scanner_controversy_ucsf_r.php|title=TSA Scanners: U.C. San Francisco Radiologists Debunk Radiation Fears|author=Smiley, Lauren |date=November 2010|publisher=SFWeekly}}</ref> "The conclusions are wrong," Ronald Arenson, professor of radiology, tells SF Weekly of his own institution's letter. "People who are totally unrelated to radiation wrote it. ... It was senior faculty at UCSF. They're smart people and well-intended, but their conclusions, I think, were off-base. They don't understand how radiation translates to an actual dose in the human body".
Dr. Steve Smith, inventor of the body scanner in 1991, and president of Tek84, one of the companies that produces the machines, has stated that the concerns of Dr. Brenner and UCSF Scientists regarding the skin dose of backscatter scanners are incorrect. He states the values used for X-ray penetration were incorrectly based on the description of the imaging depth which describes what the instrument sees and is a few mm into the skin and the dosage depth which is deeper. He describes experimental proof that the X-rays have the same properties as any other X-Rays and the penetration is correct to be averaged over the whole body. Dr. Smith has provided measured data from an operating body scanner to explain his position.<ref>[http://www.tek84.com/downloads/Holt-Letter2010-12-2.pdf re: Misinformation on airport body scanner radiation safety] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716203604/http://www.tek84.com/downloads/Holt-Letter2010-12-2.pdf |date=July 16, 2011 }}. A letter to Rush Holt. Tek84. December 2, 2010</ref>
In October 2010, The TSA responded to the concerns of UCSF researchers via the White House science advisor.<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/RadiationEmittingProductsandProcedures/SecuritySystems/ucm231857.htm Response to University of California – San Francisco Regarding Their Letter of Concern, October 12, 2010]. Fda.gov. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2010/11/08/backscatter-back-story Backscatter Back-Story | The White House]. Whitehouse.gov (November 8, 2010). Retrieved on 2011-11-01.</ref>
Scanners also concentrate the dose in time, because they deliver a high dose-rate at the moment of exposure. High dose-rate exposure has been shown to cause greater damage than the same radiation dose delivered at lower rates.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0167-8140(86)80181-5|title=Dose-rate effects and the repair of radiation damage|year=1986|last1=Gordonsteel|first1=G|last2=Down|first2=J|last3=Peacock|first3=J|last4=Stephens|first4=T|journal=Radiotherapy and Oncology|volume=5|issue=4|pages=321–31|pmid=3726169}}</ref> This raises further questions about comparisons to background radiation.
The FDA report states:
<blockquote>Since general-use x-ray systems emit ionizing radiation, the societal benefit of reliably detecting threats must be sufficient to outweigh the potential radiation risk, if any, to the individual screened. The dose from one screening with a general-use x-ray security screening system is so low that it presents an extremely small risk to any individual. To put the radiation dose received into perspective: * Naturally occurring ionizing radiation is all around us. We are continuously exposed to this background radiation during ordinary living. In 42 minutes of ordinary living, a person receives more radiation from naturally occurring sources than from screening with any general-use x-ray security system. * The national radiation safety standard (see below) sets a dose per screening limit for the general-use category. To meet the requirements of the general-use category a full-body x-ray security system must deliver less than the dose a person receives during 4 minutes of airline flight. TSA has set their dose limit to ensure a person receives less radiation from one scan with a TSA general-use x-ray security system than from 2 minutes of airline flight. * A person would have to be screened more than a thousand times in one year in order to exceed the annual radiation dose limit for people screening that has been set by expert radiation safety organizations (see below). * Millimeter wave security systems which comply with the limits set in the applicable national non-ionizing radiation safety standard (see below) cause no known adverse health effects.</blockquote>
The U.S. TSA has also made public various independent safety assessments of the Secure 1000 Backscatter X-ray Scanner.<ref>[http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/tsa_safety_study_ait_info_memo.pdf Memo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215113224/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/tsa_safety_study_ait_info_memo.pdf |date=December 15, 2011 }}. (PDF) . tsa.gov.</ref><ref>[http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v1.pdf Johns Hopkins Lab Full Report version 1] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205092128/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v1.pdf |date=February 5, 2011 }}. (PDF) . Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v2.pdf Johns Hopkins Lab Full Report version 2] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419204023/http://www.tsa.gov/assets/pdf/jh_apl_v2.pdf |date=April 19, 2011 }}. (PDF) . Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
Dr. David Brenner, head of Columbia University's center for radiological research, said although the danger posed to the individual passenger is "very low", he is urging researchers to carry out more tests on the device to look at the way it affects specific groups who could be more sensitive to radiation.
Dr. Andrew J. Einstein, director of cardiac CT research at Columbia University, has made the following statements in support of the safety of body scanners:<ref name="businessweek.com" />: "A passenger would need to be scanned using a backscatter scanner, from both the front and the back, about 200,000 times to receive the amount of radiation equal to one typical CT scan," said Dr. Andrew J. Einstein, director of cardiac CT research at Columbia University Medical Center in New York City. "Another way to look at this is that if you were scanned with a backscatter scanner every day of your life, you would still only receive a tenth of the dose of a typical CT scan," he said. "By comparison, the amount of radiation from a backscatter scanner is equivalent to about 10 minutes of natural background radiation in the United States", Einstein said. "I believe that the general public has nothing to worry about in terms of the radiation from airline scanning," he added. "For moms-to-be, no evidence supports an increased risk of miscarriage or fetal abnormalities from these scanners", Einstein added. "A pregnant woman will receive much more radiation from cosmic rays she is exposed to while flying than from passing through a scanner in the airport," he claimed.
In May 2010 the National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements issued a press release in response to the health risk claims from UCSF and Columbia University (claims of excessive skin dose and risks to large populations vs. individuals). The NCRP claims that cancer risks cited by opponents are completely inaccurate, stating that:<ref>[http://www.ncrponline.org/Press_Rel/Commentaries/Comm_16_Press_Release.pdf Structural Shielding Design and Evaluation for Megavoltage Radiotherapy Facilities]. (PDF) . Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
<blockquote> the summation of trivial average risks over very large populations or time periods into a single value produces a distorted image of risk, completely out of perspective with risks accepted every day, both voluntarily and involuntarily.</blockquote>
and that
<blockquote>general-use systems should adhere to an effective dose of 0.1 microsievert (μSv) (0.01 millirem) or less per scan, and can be used mostly without regard to the number of individuals scanned or the number of scans per individual in a year. An effective dose of 0.1 μSv (0.01 mrem) per scan would allow 2,500 scans of an individual annually [i.e., if each scan required 0.1 μSv (0.01 mrem)] without exceeding the administrative control of 0.25 mSv (25 mrem) to a member of the general public for a single source or set of sources under one control. Assuming 250 workdays per year, this would correspond to an average of 10 scans each day, a frequency that is unlikely to be encountered.</blockquote>
All the same the [[Inter-Agency Committee on Radiation Safety]] which includes the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], [[Nuclear Energy Agency]] and the [[World Health Organization]], reported that, "Pregnant women and children should not be subject to scanning, even though the radiation dose from body scanners is 'extremely small'".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aoG.YbbvnkzU&pos=11|title=Airport Body Scanning Raises Radiation Exposure, Committee Says|author=Tirone, Jonathan |publisher=Bloomberg|date=February 5, 2010}}</ref>
It has also been suggested that defects in the machines, damage from normal wear-and-tear, or software errors could focus an intense dose of radiation on just one spot of the body. The researchers write:<ref name="scribd.com">[https://www.scribd.com/doc/35498347/UCSF-letter-to-Holdren-concerning-health-risks-of-full-body-scanner-TSA-screenings-4-6-2010 UCSF letter to Holdren concerning health risks of full body scanner TSA screenings 4-6-2010]. Scribd.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
<blockquote>Moreover, there are a number of 'red flags' related to the hardware itself. Because this device can scan a human in a few seconds, the X-ray beam is very intense. Any glitch in power at any point in the hardware (or more importantly in software) that stops the device could cause an intense radiation dose to a single spot on the skin. Who will oversee problems with overall dose after repair or software problems? The TSA is already complaining about resolution limitations; who will keep the manufacturers and/or TSA from just raising the dose, an easy way to improve signal-to-noise and get higher resolution? Lastly, given the recent incident (on December 25th), how do we know whether the manufacturer or TSA, seeking higher resolution, will scan the groin area more slowly leading to a much higher total dose?</blockquote>
Proponents of backscatter X-ray scanners argue that the [[ANSI N43.17 standard]] addresses safety requirements and engineering design of the systems to prevent the occurrence of accidental high radiation due to defects and errors in hardware and software. Safety requirements include "fail-safe" controls, multiple overlapping interlocks and engineering design to ensure that failure of any systems result in safe or non-operation of the system to reduce the chance of accidental exposures. Furthermore, TSA requires that certification to the ANSI N43.17 standard is performed by a third party and not by the manufacturer themselves.<ref>ANSI N43.17 (2009) section 7.2.1 and 7.2.2</ref>{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}} But there are cases where types of medical scanning machines, operated by trained medical personnel, have malfunctioned, causing serious injury to patients that were scanned.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/01/health/01radiation.html|title=After Stroke Scans, Patients Face Serious Health Risks|author=Bogdanich, Walt |publisher=New York Times|date=July 31, 2010}}</ref> Critics of full-body scanners cite these incidents as examples of how radiation-based scanning machines can overdose people with radiation despite all safety precautions.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jay-stanley/full-body-scanners-from-a_b_694466.html Jay Stanley: Full Body Scanners: From Airports to the Streets?]. Huffingtonpost.com (August 25, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> In March 2011, it was found that some of the full body scanners in the US were emitting 10 times the normal level of radiation:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.com/news/ci_17614205|title=Full-body scanners to be retested|author=Marroquin, Art |date= March 14, 2011|publisher=LA Daily News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2011/03/japan_radiation_tsa_scanners_l.php|title=Forget Japan's Radiation Cloud – Could a TSA Scanner at LAX Give You Cancer?|author=Wilson, Simone |date=March 2011|publisher=LA Weekly}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc4.com/content/news/state/story/Body-scanners-show-high-radiation-levels/FrvExvO8Z0yts2GAoV6Abw.cspx|title=Body scanners show high radiation levels|publisher=abc4}}</ref> Contractors charged with routinely examining the scanners submitted reports containing discrepancies, including mathematical miscalculations showing that some of the devices emitted radiation levels 10 times higher than normal: "In our review of the surveys we found instances where a technician incorrectly did his math and came up with results that showed the radiation readings were off by a factor of 10," said Peter Kant, executive vice president of Rapiscan Systems.
The x-rays from backscatter scanners "are a form of ionizing radiation, that is, radiation powerful enough to strip molecules in the body of their electrons, creating charged particles that cause cell damage and are thought to be the mechanism through which radiation causes cancer."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/09/health/09scanner.html | work=The New York Times | title=Cancer Risks Debated for Type of X-Ray Scan | first=Matthew L. | last=Wald | date=January 9, 2010}}</ref> Humans are exposed to background radiation every day, anywhere on earth,<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/rpdweb00/understand/calculate.html Calculate Your Radiation Dose | Radiation Protection]. US EPA (June 28, 2006). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> and proponents of backscatter X-ray scanners say that the devices expose subjects to levels of radiation equivalent to background radiation. Furthermore, when traveling on an airplane, passengers are exposed to much higher levels of radiation than on earth due to altitude. Proponents say that a backscatter X-ray scan is equivalent to the radiation received during two minutes of flying.<ref>[http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/safety.shtm TSA: Safety] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709173835/http://www.tsa.gov/approach/tech/ait/safety.shtm |date=July 9, 2010 }}. Tsa.gov. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
The UK Health Protection Agency has also issued a statement that the radiation dose from backscatter scanners is very low and "about the same as one hour of background radiation".<ref>[http://www.hpa.org.uk/Topics/Radiation/UnderstandingRadiation/UnderstandingRadiationTopics/BodyScanners/ Body scanning at airports] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124000000/http://www.hpa.org.uk/Topics/Radiation/UnderstandingRadiation/UnderstandingRadiationTopics/BodyScanners/ |date=November 24, 2010 }}. HPA. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
The [[European Commission]] issued a report stating that backscatter x-ray scanners pose no known health risk, but suggested that backscatter x-ray scanners, which expose people to ionizing radiation, should not be used when millimeter-wave scanners that "have less effects on the human body" are available:<ref>[http://www.riseproject.eu/_fileupload/ETHICS%20OF%20BODY%20SCANNER%20POLICY%20REPORT%20NEW.pdf Microsoft Word – Ethics Of Body Scanner Policy Report]. (PDF) Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
Assuming all other conditions equal, there is no reason to adopt X‐ray backscatters, which expose the subject to an additional – although negligible – source of ionizing radiations. Other WBI <nowiki>[Whole Body Imaging]</nowiki> technologies should be preferred for standard use. However, the European Commission's report provides no data substantiating the claim that "all other conditions are equal". One area where backscatter X-ray scanners can provide better performance than millimeter wave scanners, for example, is in the inspection of the shoes, groin and armpit regions of the body.<ref>[http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner-more.html Tek84] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506113432/http://www.tek84.com/bodyscanner-more.html |date=May 6, 2014 }}. Tek84 (March 17, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> The European Commission also recommended that alternate screening methods should be "used on pregnant women, babies, children and people with disabilities".<ref name="travel.usatoday.com">Stoller, Gary. (July 13, 2010) [http://travel.usatoday.com/flights/2010-07-13-1Abodyscans13_ST_N.htm Backlash grows against full-body scanners in airports]. Travel.usatoday.com. Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
In the United States, Senator [[Susan Collins]], Ranking Member of the [[United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs|Senate Homeland Security Committee]] sent a letter on August 6, 2010 to the Secretary of Homeland Security and Administrator of the TSA, requesting that the TSA "have the Department’s Chief Medical Officer, working with independent experts, conduct a review of the health effects of their use for travelers, TSA employees, and airport and airline personnel."<ref>[http://hsgac.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=Press.MinorityNews&ContentRecord_id=48bdf98d-5056-8059-76f0-36d9d201328e&IsTextOnly=False United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Government Affairs : Press]. Hsgac.senate.gov (August 6, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> The TSA has completed this review.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}}
The U.S. Government is also supplying higher-radiation through-body [[X-Ray machine]]s to at least two African countries "for the purposes of airport security — the kind that can see through flesh, and which deliver real doses of radiation. The U.S.-supplied scanners have apparently been deployed at one airport in Ghana and four in Nigeria".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gsnmagazine.com/article/20428/ghana_adds_soter_through_body_x_ray_security_scann|date=April 6, 2010 |title=Ghana adds Soter through-body X-Ray security scanner|author=Chunovic, Louis |publisher=GSN}}</ref> which has caused some to question how far the U.S. Government intends to go with the technology.<ref>Stanley, Jay (April 8, 2010) [https://www.aclu.org/blog/national-security-technology-and-liberty/us-encouraging-use-radiation-africans Is the U.S. Encouraging the Use of Radiation on Africans?]. Aclu.org. Retrieved on November 1, 2011.</ref>
Unions for airline pilots working for American Airlines and US Airways have urged pilots to avoid the full body scanners.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/money_co/2010/11/body-scanners-pilots.html|title=Unions urge pilots to avoid body scanners at airports|author=Martín, Hugo |publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=November 11, 2010}}</ref>
===Child scanning=== There is controversy over full-body scanners in some countries because the machines create images of virtual strip searches on persons under the age of 18 which may violate child pornography laws. In the UK, the scanners may be breaking the [[Protection of Children Act 1978|Protection of Children Act of 1978]] by creating images or pseudo-images of nude children.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/jan/04/new-scanners-child-porn-laws New scanners break child porn laws | Politics]. The Guardian. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref><ref>[https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/01/body-scanners/ Body Scanners Might Violate U.K. Child-Protection Laws | Threat Level]. Wired.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
Parents have complained that their young children are being virtually strip searched, sometimes without their parents present.<ref>[http://www.tampabay.com/news/transportation/airport-body-scanners-reveal-all-but-what-about-when-its-your-kid/1109659 "Airport body scanners reveal all, but what about when it's your kid?"], ''St. Petersburg Times''. Tampabay.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref>
===Ineffectiveness=== Some critics suggest that full-body scanner technology is ineffective for multiple reasons, including that they can easily be bypassed and a study published in the November 2010 edition of the ''Journal of Transportation Security'' suggested terrorists might fool the Rapiscan machines and others like it employing the X-ray "backscatter" technique. A terrorist, the report found, could tape a thin film of explosives of about 15–20 centimeters in diameter to the stomach and walk through the machine undetected.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/03/scanners-part3/ |title=Airport 'Nude' Body Scanners: Are They Effective? |publisher=Wired.com |date=March 8, 2011 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref>
Terrorists have already evolved their tactics with the use of surgically implanted bombs or bombs hidden in body cavities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/body-scanners-no-match-for-latest-terror-ploy-surgically-implanted-bombs-20100131-n6jx.html|title=Body scanners no match for latest terror ploy: surgically implanted bombs|author=Heasley, Andrew |publisher=The Age|location=Melbourne|date=February 1, 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/09/28/eveningnews/main5347847.shtml Al Qaeda Bombers Learn from Drug Smugglers]. CBS News (September 28, 2009). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
In March 2012, scientist and blogger Jonathan Corbett demonstrated the ineffectiveness of the machines by publishing a viral video showing how he was able to get a metal box through backscatter x-ray and millimeter wave scanners in two US airports.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com/2012/03/06/1b-of-nude-body-scanners-made-worthless-by-blog-how-anyone-can-get-anything-past-the-tsas-nude-body-scanners/ |title=$1B of TSA Nude Body Scanners Made Worthless By Blog – How Anyone Can Get Anything Past The Scanners |publisher=Tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com |date=March 6, 2012 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Moscaritolo |first=Angela |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2401276,00.asp |title=Blogger Says TSA's Full-Body Scanners Can be Easily Duped |publisher=Pcmag.com |date=March 7, 2012 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> In April 2012, Corbett released a second video interviewing a TSA screener, who described firearms and simulated explosives passing through the scanners during internal testing and training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com/2012/04/10/tsa-admits-1b-nude-body-scanner-fleet-worthless/ |title=TSA Admits $1B Nude Body Scanner Fleet Worthless! |publisher=Tsaoutofourpants.wordpress.com |date=April 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref> In another test of the full-body scanners, the machines failed to detect bomb parts hidden around a person's body.<ref>[http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2010/01/german_tv_on_th.html Schneier on Security: German TV on the Failure of Full-Body Scanners]. Schneier.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref> And in a different test in 2011, an undercover TSA agent was able to carry a handgun through full body scanners multiple times without the weapon being detected. However, fault was not that of the machine, but the TSA Agent who was in charge of viewing the scanned images was simply not paying attention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local-beat/TSA-Agent-Slips-Through-DFW-Body-Scanner-With-a-Gun-116497568.html|title=TSA Source: Armed Agent Slips Past DFW Body Scanner|author=Stinchfield, Grant |date=February 21, 2011|publisher=NBC}}</ref>
Furthermore an Israeli airport security expert Rafi Sela, who helped design security at [[Ben Gurion International Airport]], has said: "I don't know why everybody is running to buy these expensive and useless machines. I can overcome the body scanners with enough explosives to bring down a Boeing 747... That's why we haven't put them in our airport."<ref>Levi Julian, Hana (25 April, 2010) [http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/137184 Israeli Security Expert to Canada: 'Full Body Scanners Useless']. israelnationalnews.com</ref>
Again, despite the scanners, the TSA has been unable to stop weapons like box cutters and pistols from being carried onto airplanes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travelmole.com/stories/1146729.php|title=TSA can’t even find box-cutters|author=Wilkening, David|date=March 10, 2011 |publisher=TravelMole}}</ref>
The Australia government has been challenged over the effectiveness and cost of full body scanners by public media to which Australian Transport Minister [[Anthony Albanese]] has said he "makes no apologies" for mandating the installation of full body scanners at Australian airports.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/security-a-safe-market-20111108-1n5hi.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Security a safe market}}</ref>
Two alternatives that have been argued for by experts, such as Prof Chris Mayhew from Birmingham University, are chemical-based scanners and bomb-sniffing dogs.<ref>[http://www.theengineer.co.uk/news/full-body-scanners-spark-concerns/1000459.article Full-body scanners spark concerns | News]. The Engineer (January 5, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref> Others have argued that [[Predictive profiling|passenger profiling]], as done by Israeli airport security, should replace full body scanners and patdowns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philly2philly.com/politics_community/politics_community_articles/2010/11/26/45712/airport_full_body_scanners_should_be|title=Airport Full Body Scanners Should Be Abandoned in Favor of Profiling|author=Uliasz, Erik |date=November 26, 2010|publisher=Philly2Philly}}</ref>
===US Public opinion=== A Gallup poll given just after the [[Northwest Airlines Flight 253|2009 Christmas Day bombing attempt]] suggested that 78% of American airline travelers approved of body scanners while 20% disapproved. 51% indicated that they would have some level of discomfort with full-body scans, while 48% said they would not be uncomfortable with the idea.<ref>[http://www.gallup.com/poll/125018/Air-Travelers-Body-Scans-Stride.aspx In U.S., Air Travelers Take Body Scans in Stride]. Gallup.com. Retrieved on September 26, 2010.</ref> The poll was given in the context of the 2009 Christmas Day bombing attempt, and some opponents of full body scanners say that the explosives used in that bombing attempt would not have been detected by full-body scanners.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/are-planned-airport-scanners-just-a-scam-1856175.html Are planned airport scanners just a scam? – Home News, UK]. ''The Independent'' (January 3, 2010). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
An ABC/Washington Post poll conducted by Langer Associates and released November 22, 2010 found that 64 percent of Americans favored the full-body X-ray scanners, but that 50 percent think the "enhanced" pat-downs go too far; 37 percent felt so strongly. In addition the poll states opposition is lowest amongst those who fly less than once a year.<ref>Silver, Nate (November 22, 2010) [http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/11/22/new-poll-suggests-shift-in-public-views-on-t-s-a-procedures/ New Poll Suggests Shift in Public Views on T.S.A. Procedures]. ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref>
As of November 23, 2010 an online poll of 11,817 people on [[The Consumerist]] website, 59.41% said they would not fly as a result of the new scans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://consumerist.com/2010/11/you-might-be-in-serious-for-refusing-to-be-tsa-screened.html |title= You Might be in serious trouble for refusing to be screened |publisher=Consumerist.com |date= |accessdate=November 22, 2010}}</ref> Additionally, as of November 23, 2010 a poll of [[MSNBC]] 8,500 online readers indicated 84.1% believe the new procedures would not increase travel safety.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://travel.newsvine.com/_question/2010/11/17/5482236-do-you-support-the-tsas-enhanced-security-procedures?pc=20&sp=2 |title=Do you support the TSA's Enhanced Security Procedures |publisher=MSNBC.com |date= |accessdate=November 22, 2010}}</ref> According to a CBS telephone poll of 1,137 people published in November 2010, 81% (+/- 5%) percent of those polled approved TSA's use of full-body scans.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/11/15/politics/main7057902.shtml?tag=contentMain;contentBody | work=CBS News | title=CBS News Poll: 11/15/10 | date=November 15, 2010}}</ref>
There has been some debate about the safety of the scanners, however, the TSA argue that mmw scanners used emit no ionizing radiation.<ref>Poynton, Aaron Sean (May 4, 2011). [http://www.domesticpreparedness.com/Infrastructure/Transportation/Whole-Body_Imaging%3A_A_Safe_Alternative_to_the_%60Pat_Down%60 Whole-Body Imaging: A Safe Alternative to the 'Pat Down']. ''Domestic Preparedness Journal''.</ref>
===Full-body scanner lobbyists=== Former Homeland Security secretary [[Michael Chertoff]] has been criticized for heavily promoting full-body scanners while not always fully disclosing that he is a lobbyist for one of the companies that makes the machines.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/31/AR2009123102821.html Ex-Homeland Security chief head said to abuse public trust by touting body scanners]. washingtonpost.com (December 31, 2009). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://motherjones.com/mojo/2010/01/airport-scanner-scam|title=The Airport Scanner Scam|author=Ridgeway, James |date=January 2010|publisher=Mother Jones}}</ref> Other full-body scanner lobbyists with Government connections include:<ref>[http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/opinion/blogs/beltway-confidential/The-TSA-and-the-full-body-scanner-lobby-80284847.html The TSA and the full-body-scanner lobby]. Washington Examiner (December 29, 2009). Retrieved on 2010-09-26.</ref>
* former TSA deputy administration Tom Blank * former assistant administrator for policy at the [[Transportation Security Administration|TSA]], Chad Wolf * Kevin Patrick Kelly, "a former top staffer to Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., who sits on the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee" * Former Senator [[Al D'Amato]]
===TSA's expansion of scanning program===
Forbes magazine reported, in March 2011, that:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2011/03/02/docs-reveal-tsa-plan-to-body-scan-pedestrians-train-passengers|title=Documents Reveal TSA Research Proposal To Body-Scan Pedestrians, Train Passengers|author=Greenberg, Andy |date=March 2, 2011|publisher=Forbes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2011/03/09/tsa-never-tested-full-body-scans-for-mass-transit-except-when-it-did|title=TSA Never Tested Full-Body Scans For Mass Transit, Except When It Did|author=Greenberg, Andy |publisher=Forbes|date=March 9, 2011}}</ref>
<blockquote>Newly uncovered documents show that as early as 2006, the Department of Homeland Security has been planning pilot programs to deploy mobile scanning units that can be set up at public events and in train stations, along with mobile x-ray vans capable of scanning pedestrians on city streets.</blockquote>
and that the TSA had research proposals to:
<blockquote>bring full-body scanners to train stations, mass transit, and public events. Contracts included in the EPIC release showed plans to develop long-range scans that could assess what a subject carried from 30 feet away, along with studies that involved systems for x-ray scanners mounted in vans and "covert" scans of pedestrians.</blockquote>
==="No nudity" full-body scanner=== The new software for scanners has been applied by US Aviation Security, so the new full-body scanner will not give image of nudity of the person who is scanned to the operators of the scanner, but only give the image as a generic male or female figure with no features. Opponents of full body scanners still consider this to be an unconstitutional strip search, because even though the operators see an edited version of the image, a naked image is still captured by the machine, and there is no guarantee that the Government or private companies won't store the images in the case that a terrorist attack were successful.
This type of software has been applied at Washington, Atlanta and Las Vegas airports.<ref>{{cite web|last=Halsey |first=Ashley |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/travel/2015670654_nudescanners21.html |title=New airport software to end naked scanner images |publisher=Seattletimes.com |date= |accessdate=December 19, 2016}}</ref>
"Our top priority is the safety of the traveling public, and TSA constantly strives to explore and implement new technologies that enhance security and strengthen privacy protections for the traveling public," TSA Administrator John Pistole stated. "This software upgrade enables us to continue providing a high level of security through advanced imaging technology screening, while improving the passenger experience at checkpoints." <ref>{{cite news|last=Hachman|first=Mark|title=No more 'naked' full body airport scans after TSA upgrade|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2388855,00.asp|publisher=PCMAG|accessdate=April 14, 2012}}</ref>
==Technical countermeasures== Some people wish to prevent either the loss of privacy or the possibility of health problems or genetic damage that might be associated with being subjected to a backscatter X-ray scan. One company sells X-ray absorbing underwear which is said to have X-ray absorption equivalent to 0.5 mm of lead.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rockyflatsgear.com/ |title=Rocky Flats Gear X-ray protection |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901143535/http://www.rockyflatsgear.com/ |archivedate=September 1, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> Another product, Flying Pasties, is "... designed to obscure the most private parts of the human body when entering full body airport scanners", but its description does not seem to claim any protection from the X-ray beam penetrating the body of the person being scanned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyingpasties.com/ |title=Flying Pasties |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601134012/http://flyingpasties.com/ |archivedate=June 1, 2013 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[3D body scanning]] * [[Explosives trace-detection portal machine]] (puffer machine) * [[Full-body CT scan]] (in [[medical imaging]])
